title: Question 80

children: A 24-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department during the winter for headache and fever of 3 days' duration. She lives in Minnesota. Medical history is noncontributory, and her only medication is ibuprofen for headaches.
On physical examination, temperature is 38 °C (100.4 °F). Other vital signs are normal. Other than a stiff neck and photophobia, the physical examination is normal.
A CT of the head with contrast is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Viral meningitis is the most common cause of “aseptic” meningitis, with negative cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Gram stain and cultures, slightly increased leukocyte count, slightly elevated CSF protein level, and normal CSF glucose level.
Herpes simplex virus type 2 is most commonly associated with meningitis, occurs year round, and is the most common cause of recurrent meningitis.
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is meningitis caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 2 (

). Viral meningitis is the most common cause of “aseptic” meningitis, in which cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Gram stain and cultures are negative. Viral meningitis usually presents with a mild pleocytosis (50-1000/µL [50-1000 × 10

/L]), mildly elevated CSF protein level (<200 mg/dL [2000 mg/L]), and a normal CSF glucose level (>45 mg/dL [2.5 mmol/L]). Patients with viral meningitis may present with a neutrophilic pleocytosis in the first 24 to 48 hours, which typically becomes lymphocytic predominant. Most patients have typical meningitis symptoms such as fever, nuchal rigidity, headache, and photophobia. HSV-2 is more commonly associated with meningitis, occurs year round, and is the most common cause of recurrent meningitis (recurrent benign lymphocytic meningitis). Outcomes for HSV-2 meningitis are generally favorable without the need for acyclovir therapy.

) are the most common cause of viral meningitis but usually present between May and November in the Western hemisphere, with symptoms including headache, fever, nuchal rigidity, photophobia, nausea, vomiting, myalgia, pharyngitis, maculopapular rash, and cough. Presentation in the winter makes this an unlikely cause of this patient's illness. CSF polymerase chain reaction studies may be used to rapidly diagnose HSV and enterovirus meningitis.

) is the most common cause of sporadic encephalitis in the United States and can occur year round. HSV-1 encephalitis presents with fever, seizures, altered mental status, and focal neurologic deficits.

) is a mosquito-borne illness that may also have a similar clinical presentation and CSF profile as HSV-2 meningitis, but it occurs between June and October. West Nile virus may also present with meningoencephalitis or as an isolated myelitis. In its most severe form, infection of the anterior horn cells can cause a symmetric or asymmetric flaccid paralysis, analogous to that previously seen with polio. The diagnosis can be confirmed through identification of the IgM antibody in CSF.

references: Shukla B, Aguilera EA, Salazar L, et al. Aseptic meningitis in adults and children: Diagnostic and management challenges. J Clin Virol. 2017;94:110-114.
